instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turn on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turn on
threads.message:
History? 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is basically the VDD main rail which powers the PMU. The PMU powers the T2, which talks to the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> USB C controllers. 

What do you ask yourself if you find a missing voltage? Is it shorted! 

Find out, and get back to us.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turn on
threads.message: To avoid any missunderstood, do you talk about L7660 (<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>), or L6900/1 (<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turn on
threads.message:
Try several times DFU revive and restore.
Check if SSD and G3S voltages appear.

Just in case, reflash <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> and try again.
Don't forget to make backup in such case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turn on
threads.message:
If USB-C inputs switch all to 20V, the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips should be good.
There may be a communication problem with external USB device, but good communication with the charger at least; not usual case at all.

If you have different behavior between USB-C charging ports, there could still be a bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turn on
threads.message:
Need to reball that <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip.
Also clean the corrosion, replace damaged components and rebuild traces, if needed.
